nodes.bodyText: It is not necessary to provide a specific string to specify the Mock behavior. You can simply use any(String.class) as the parameter to readValue instead of an actual string. Then you can specify any string you want when you actually make the call to your service's readFlower method.

Similarly, you can use any(String.class) here. But there is no reason to actually specify an invalid JSON string when calling your service. If you do, then what is the point of mocking the behavior? That is the actual exception that would be thrown when reading an invalid JSON string if you did not mock the readValue method.
Same applies here as in the other test class. By the way, this reinforces my earlier thought that we don't need to involve Spring at all and should probably move this code to a different module.
Note: we generally static import all mockito methods.
and we generally static import assertions too
Since we only use this once and it's a one-liner, let's just move it to the flowerHasPetals method to simplify the call stack.
